leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,750] s 182 Application of certain sections in relation to Commonwealth records

leg:heading.title: Application of certain sections in relation to Commonwealth records

p.text: The Commonwealth Act includes a provision that extends the operation of certain provisions of the Commonwealth Act to Commonwealth records.
If a question arises about the application of a provision of this Act in relation to a document or thing, the court may:
examine the document or thing, and
draw any reasonable inferences from it as well as from other matters from which inferences may properly be drawn.
Section 182 of the Commonwealth Act gives section 183 of the Commonwealth Act a wider application in relation to Commonwealth records and certain Commonwealth documents.
[s 183 am Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1]

The provisions of s 183 merely enable a document to be examined, and reasonable inferences drawn from such parts of it as are admissible or to which no objection has been taken: Ocean Marine Mutual Insurance Association (Europe) OV v Jetopay Pty Ltd (2000) 120 FCR 146 at 151; [2000] FCA 1463; BC200007242 ; Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW v Tetley [2004] NSWSC 925; BC200406795 .
Legislation cited in [51,755.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 58.
There is a further power of inspection in s 58 of the Act. As to the possible undesirability of inspection in some cases see [21.2.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,760] s 184 Accused may admit matters and give consents

leg:heading.title: Accused may admit matters and give consents

p.text: In or before a criminal proceeding, a defendant may:
admit matters of fact, and
give any consent,
that a party to a civil proceeding may make or give.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[73], effective 1 January 2009]
A defendant’s admission or consent is not effective for the purposes of subsection (1) unless:
the defendant has been advised to do so by his or her Australian legal practitioner or legal counsel, or
the court is satisfied that the defendant understands the consequences of making the admission or giving the consent.
[subs (2) insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[74], effective 1 January 2009]

level.toc-caption: [51,760.5] Consent to the tender of statements

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,760.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 184, s 184(2), s 190.

heading.title: Consent to the tender of statements

p.text: Although not regarded as general practice, the provisions of s 184 (and those of s 190 ) permit substantive evidence in a criminal proceeding to be given by the tender of witness statements (see R v Zvonaric (2001) 54 NSWLR 1; 127 A Crim R 9; [2001] NSWCCA 505; BC200108141 ), providing one of the two conditions for which provision is made in s 184(2) is met.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,765] s 185 Full faith and credit to be given to documents properly authenticated

leg:heading.title: Full faith and credit to be given to documents properly authenticated

p.text: The Commonwealth Act includes a provision requiring full faith and credit to be given to the public acts, records and judicial proceedings of a State or Territory.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,770] s 186 Swearing of affidavits before justices of the peace, notaries public and lawyers

leg:heading.title: Swearing of affidavits before justices of the peace, notaries public and lawyers

p.text: The Commonwealth Act includes a provision about swearing of affidavits before justices of the peace, notaries public and lawyers for use in court proceedings involving the exercise of federal jurisdiction and in courts of a Territory.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,775] s 187 No privilege against self-incrimination for bodies corporate

leg:heading.title: No privilege against self-incrimination for bodies corporate

p.text: This section applies if, under a law of the State or in a proceeding, a body corporate is required to:
answer a question or give information, or
produce a document or any other thing, or
do any other act whatever.

The body corporate is not entitled to refuse or fail to comply with the requirement on the ground that answering the question, giving the information, producing the document or other thing or doing that other act, as the case may be, might tend to incriminate the body or make the body liable to a penalty.

The privilege against self incrimination in respect of corporations was previously abolished by the High Court in Environment Protection Authority v Caltex Refining Co Pty Ltd (1993) 178 CLR 477; 118 ALR 392 (see note to s 128 at [51,135.30]). For the purposes of the section, the Crown in the right of a State is a body corporate: WorkCover Authority of New South Wales v Crown in the right of the State of New South Wales (2000) 50 NSWLR 333; 102 IR 252; [2000] NSWIRComm 234 .

The court may direct that a document that has been tendered or produced before the court (whether or not it is admitted in evidence) is to be impounded and kept in the custody of an officer of the court or of another person for such period, and subject to such conditions, as the court thinks fit.
If the determination of a question whether:
evidence should be admitted (whether in the exercise of a discretion or not), or
evidence can be used against a person, or
a witness is competent or compellable,
depends on the court finding that a particular fact exists, the question whether that fact exists is, for the purposes of this section, a preliminary question.
If there is a jury, a preliminary question whether:
particular evidence is evidence of an admission, or evidence to which section 138 (Discretion to exclude improperly or illegally obtained evidence) applies, or
evidence of an admission, or evidence to which section 138 applies, should be admitted,
is to be heard and determined in the jury's absence.

In the hearing of a preliminary question about whether a defendant's admission should be admitted into evidence (whether in the exercise of a discretion or not) in a criminal proceeding, the issue of the admission's truth or untruth is to be disregarded unless the issue is introduced by the defendant.
If there is a jury, the jury is not to be present at a hearing to decide any other preliminary question unless the court so orders.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to make such an order, it is to take into account:
whether the evidence to be adduced in the course of that hearing is likely to be prejudicial to the defendant, and
whether the evidence concerned will be adduced in the course of the hearing to decide the preliminary question, and

whether the evidence to be adduced in the course of that hearing would be admitted if adduced at another stage of the hearing (other than in another hearing to decide a preliminary question or, in a criminal proceeding, a hearing in relation to sentencing).
Section 128(10) does not apply to a hearing to decide a preliminary question.
[subs (6) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[75], effective 1 January 2009]
In the application of Chapter 3 to a hearing to determine a preliminary question, the facts in issue are taken to include the fact to which the hearing relates.
If a jury in a proceeding was not present at a hearing to determine a preliminary question, evidence is not to be adduced in the proceeding of evidence given by a witness at the hearing unless:
it is inconsistent with other evidence given by the witness in the proceeding, or
the witness has died.

The provisions of s 189 allow an examination on the voir dire when (inter alia) an issue arises as to the admissibility of evidence. However, it remains open to a judge to reject an application that a voir dire be conducted if no real preliminary question arises. In circumstances where a voir dire has commenced following which it becomes apparent that there is no preliminary question which arises, the trial judge retains a power to terminate the voir dire: R v Lee (NSWCCA, 60274 of 1996, 5 May 1997, unreported, BC9703048). The section does not confer a power upon the court to make a ruling in advance as to how a particular discretion might be exercised: see R v TKWJ (2002) 212 CLR 124; 193 ALR 7; 76 ALJR 1579; [2002] HCA 46; BC200205984 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,790] s 190 Waiver of rules of evidence

p.text: The court may, if the parties consent, by order dispense with the application of any one or more of the provisions of:
Division 3 , 4 or 5 of Part 2.1, or
Part 2.2 or 2.3 , or
in relation to particular evidence or generally.
In a criminal proceeding, a defendant's consent is not effective for the purposes of subsection (1) unless:
the defendant has been advised to do so by his or her Australian legal practitioner or legal counsel, or
the court is satisfied that the defendant understands the consequences of giving the consent.
[subs (2) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[10], effective 1 January 2009]
In a civil proceeding, the court may order that any one or more of the provisions mentioned in subsection (1) do not apply in relation to evidence if:
the matter to which the evidence relates is not genuinely in dispute, or
the application of those provisions would cause or involve unnecessary expense or delay.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to exercise the power conferred by subsection (3) , it is to take into account:
the importance of the evidence in the proceeding, and
the nature of the cause of action or defence and the nature of the subject-matter of the proceeding, and
the probative value of the evidence, and
the powers of the court (if any) to adjourn the hearing, to make another order or to give a direction in relation to the evidence.
ALRC 38 para 241(c)

The Act is a statute of general application. It does not displace other specific statutory regimes which govern the admissibility of certain types of evidence, such as the provisions of s 81 of the Bankruptcy Act (as to which see Re Schofield; Ex Parte Rangott v P & B Barron Pty Ltd (1997) 72 FCR 280; 143 ALR 185; BC9700552 ) or the provisions of s 109Y of the Corporations Act 2001 (as to which see Howship Holdings Pty Ltd v Leslie (No 2) (1996) 41 NSWLR 542; 133 FLR 307; BC9603984 .
In this section:
means a fact that the parties to a proceeding have agreed is not, for the purposes of the proceeding, to be disputed.
In a proceeding:
evidence is not required to prove the existence of an agreed fact, and
evidence may not be adduced to contradict or qualify an agreed fact,
unless the court gives leave.
Subsection (2) does not apply unless the agreed fact:
is stated in an agreement in writing signed by the parties or by Australian legal practitioners, legal counsel or prosecutors representing the parties and adduced in evidence in the proceeding, or
with the leave of the court, is stated by a party before the court with the agreement of all other parties.
[subs (3) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[76], effective 1 January 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,800] s 192 Leave, permission or direction may be given on terms

leg:heading.title: Leave, permission or direction may be given on terms

p.text: If, because of this Act, a court may give any leave, permission or direction, the leave, permission or direction may be given on such terms as the court thinks fit.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to give the leave, permission or direction, it is to take into account:
the extent to which to do so would be likely to add unduly to, or to shorten, the length of the hearing, and
the extent to which to do so would be unfair to a party or to a witness, and
the importance of the evidence in relation to which the leave, permission or direction is sought, and
the nature of the proceeding, and
the power (if any) of the court to adjourn the hearing or to make another order or to give a direction in relation to the evidence.
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 8 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
See the notes at [28.4.20] on the undesirability of separate determination of questions in the absence of agreed facts.
Legislation cited in [51,800.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

There are numerous provisions of the Act that require the court to grant leave, or give directions. Apart from the general powers conferred by provisions such as ss 9 and 11 , they include the following:
s 28 the sequence of examination and cross-examination
s 29 the form of questioning of witnesses
s 31 deaf and mute witnesses
s 32 reviving memory in court
s 34 reviving memory out of court
s 37 the manner of examination in chief
s 38 cross-examination of unfavourable witnesses
s 39 re-examination
s 42(4) disallowance of leading questions in cross-examination
s 45 the tender of prior inconsistent statements
s 46 the recalling of witnesses
s 49 proof of foreign documents
s 50 proof of foreign documents
s 67(4) first hand hearsay notices
s 100 tendency evidence notices
s 104 credibility cross-examination accused persons
s 108 rebutting adverse credibility evidence
s 112 cross-examination about character
s 130 public interest immunity
s 136 limiting the use of admissible evidence
s 168 time limits applicable to requests
s 188 the retention of documents
s 191 leave to adduce evidence to contradict agreed facts
s 195 publication of prohibited questions

The phrase “is to take into account” as it is used in s 192(2) means “shall” or “must” take into account. Accordingly the words of the section mandate a consideration of each of the matters set out: R v Nguyen [2002] NSWSC 60; BC200200333 ; R v Nguyen [2002] NSWSC 1254; BC200208142 ; DPP v Sinton [2000] NSWSC 473; BC200004040 ; R v Cakovski (2002) 133 A Crim R 18; [2002] NSWSC 632; BC200208134 ; although the failure of a trial judge to specifically advert to the matters set out in the section is not, of itsef indicative of error: R v Esho [2001] NSWCCA 415; BC200106511 ; R v Stevens [2001] NSWCCA 330; BC200108490 ; R v Reardon (2002) 186 FLR 1; [2002] NSWCCA 203; BC200202884 ; R v MDB [2005] NSWCCA 354; BC200509663 . Whilst the section is not exhaustive as to the matters which are to be taken into account, the weight to be accorded to the evidence which is sought to be adduced is a matter of considerable relevance in the exercise of the discretion: Stanoevski v R (2001) 202 CLR 115; 177 ALR 285; [2001] HCA 4; BC200100150 .
Where a question arises in any proceedings, being a question about:
the admissibility or use of evidence proposed to be adduced, or
the operation of a provision of this Act or another law in relation to evidence proposed to be adduced, or
the giving of leave, permission or direction under section 192 ,
the court may, if it considers it to be appropriate to do so, give a ruling or make a finding in relation to the question before the evidence is adduced in the proceedings.
[s 192A insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[77], effective 1 January 2009]
Legislation cited in [51,803.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 s 130, s 192A.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 Pt 53 rr 10, 11.
(VIC) Crimes Act 1958.

Traditionally, rulings on evidentiary questions and determinations of admissibility take place during the course of the trial. The Criminal Procedure Act 1986 (NSW) s 130 , the District Court Rules 1973 (NSW) Pt 53 rr 10 and 11 , the Crimes Act 1958 (Vic) and the Criminal Code 1924 (Tas) permit courts to determine preliminary questions prior to the commencement of a trial. Authorities in NSW proceeded on the assumption that the Evidence Act allowed for advance rulings in relation to the admissibility of evidence: R v PKS (NSWCCA, Wood CJ at CL, Sull and Ireland JJ, 60174/98, 1 Oct 1998, unreported, BC9805040) ; R v Robinson (2000) 111 A Crim R 388; [2000] NSWCCA 59; BC200001594 . However, in TKWJ v R (2002) 212 CLR 124; 193 ALR 7; [2002] HCA 46; BC200205984 the High Court held that, under the then form of the Evidence Acts, advance evidentiary rulings could only be made in some cases where leave, permission or direction had been sought.

The present s 192A confers a wider power to make advance rulings on the admissibility of evidence. In doing so, the section specifies only one test for the court to exercise its power, namely that it considers it appropriate to do so. Whether the court should make advance rulings under the section is a discretionary case management decision to be made in accordance with the overriding purpose of facilitating the just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in dispute: see Lambert Leasing Inc v QBE Insurance Australia Ltd [2012] NSWSC 953; BC201207086 at [11] and the authorities cited therein; see also NA & J Investments Pty Ltd v Minister Administering Water Management Act 2000 [2012] NSWLEC 120; BC201204062 esp at [40]. In order for the court to exercise its discretion, some good reason to warrant doing so must be advanced. However, it is not necessary for the party seeking to invoke the provisions of the section to demonstrate “special circumstances”, nor is it necessary to show that the circumstances are in some way out of the ordinary: see Sydney Attractions Group Pty Ltd v Schulman [2012] NSWSC 951; BC201207042 .
The powers of a court in relation to:
the discovery or inspection of documents, and
ordering disclosure and exchange of evidence, intended evidence, documents and reports, ordering disclosure and exchange of evidence, intended evidence, documents and reports,

extend to enabling the court to make such orders as the court thinks fit (including orders about methods of inspection, adjournments and costs) to ensure that the parties to a proceeding can adequately, and in an appropriate manner, inspect documents of the kind referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of the definition of "document" in the Dictionary.
The power of a person or body to make rules of courts extends to making rules, not inconsistent with this Act or the regulations, prescribing matters:
required or permitted by this Act to be prescribed, or
necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Act.

Without limiting subsection (2) , rules made under that subsection may provide for the discovery, exchange, inspection or disclosure of intended evidence, documents and reports of persons intended to be called by a party to give evidence in a proceeding.
Without limiting subsection (2) , rules made under that subsection may provide for the exclusion of evidence, or for its admission on specified terms, if the rules are not complied with.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,810] s 194 Witnesses failing to attend proceedings

p.text: If a witness fails to appear when called in any civil or criminal proceedings and it is proved that he or she has been duly bound by recognisance or served with a summons or subpoena, the court may:

order the witness to show cause at those or later proceedings why execution of the recognisance or an attachment for disobedience to the summons or subpoena should not be issued against the witness, or

if it is proved that the non-appearance is without just cause or reasonable excuse and that the witness will probably be able to give relevant evidence in the proceeding, issue a warrant to bring the witness before the court to give the evidence.
Matters may be proved under this section orally or by affidavit.
On return of an order to show cause under this section the court may deal with the case in the same way as the Supreme Court would deal with an order to similar effect made by that Court.

The Commonwealth Act does not include an equivalent provision to section 194 . There are provisions to the same effect in federal court rules and ACT legislation applying to proceedings before federal courts and ACT courts.
Legislation cited in [51,810.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 ss 13, 14.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.12.
(NSW) Companies Act 1961 s 367A.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 142, s 194.

The section is substantially the same as its predecessors — ss 13 and 14 of the Evidence Act 1898. It complements similar enforcement powers contained in the rules of court: see r 33.12 . In any event, wilful failure to answer a subpoena constitutes contempt and may be dealt with as such: Kingston v Cooper (1872) 41 LJ 317; Ex parte Fernandez (1861) 10 CBNS 3 ; R v Clement (1821) 4 Be & Ald 218; 106 ER 918; Re Keller (1887) 22 LR Ir 158; Price v Hutchinson (1870) LR 9 Eq 534; Ullathorne, Hartridge & Co Ltd v Green (1901) 27 VLR 22 ; R v Greenway (1845) 7 QB 126; R v Wiltshire Appeal Tribunal; Ex parte Thatcher (1916) 86 LJKB 137; James v Cowan (1929) 42 CLR 305; [1930] ALR 125 . In Re John Sanderson & Co (NSW) Pty Ltd (in liq) (No 2) [1976] VR 363 it was held that an officer of a company who failed to appear on an examination under s 367A of the Companies Act 1961 after being duly served with a subpoena to attend, rendered himself liable to be arrested and brought before the court: see the notes at [33.12.5] .

The matters which are required to be proved under s 194 must be proved on the balance of probabilities: see s 142 of the Act at [51,3015]; see also Photi v Target Australia Pty Ltd (No 2) (2007) 6 DCLR (NSW) 122; [2007] NSWDC 302 ; cf Harris/D-E Pty Ltd v McClelland's Coffee & Tea Pty Ltd (1999) 149 FLR 204 at [34]; [1999] NSWSC 36; BC9900331 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,815] s 195 Prohibited question not to be published

leg:heading.title: Prohibited question not to be published

p.text: A person must not, without the express permission of a court, print or publish:
any question that the court has disallowed under section 41 (Improper questions), or
any question that the court has disallowed because any answer that is likely to be given to the question would contravene the credibility rule, or
any question in respect of which the court has refused to give leave under Part 3.7 (Credibility).
Maximum penalty: 60 penalty units.
Proceedings for an offence against this Act or the regulations are to be dealt with summarily before the Local Court.
The Commonwealth Act does not include an equivalent provision to section 196 .
[s 196 am Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003 ; Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]

The Governor may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Act, prescribing matters for or with respect to any matter that by this Act is required or permitted to be prescribed or that is necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,830] s 198 Savings, transitional and other provisions

p.text: Schedule 2 has effect.
[s 198 insrt Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[78], effective 1 January 2009]
